text:
I am writing in support of the Fair Access to Financial Services proposed rule. Services that I use and would like to support have been routinely removed from banks and payment processors for reasons unrelated to their financial risk. Often times, these services are growing competitors to markets that have long been dominated by a single company, such as the online video platform Bitchute. It has had difficultly with payment processors over allegations of hosting hateful content, while the dominate platform, Youtube, has also been alleged to host hateful content and it does not have trouble with processing payments from its userbase. The subscription service platform NewProject2 was denied access to financial institutions due to harassment campaigns of the platform's creator, Dax Herrera. He was denied access to banks not because of his credit status, but because a small minority labeled his character as hateful. I would have loved to support content creators that use these platforms, but it has become increasingly difficult to do so as more and more financial institutions deny platforms access to themselves. I do not believe that Americans and American companies should be denied access to financial institutions for anything that does not have to do with the ability to pay back loaned money.

Outside of my personal concerns, I am worried that without the Fair Access to Financial Services rule, our nation could see people being denied access to financial institutions for political reasons. As noted in the introduction to this regulation, both family planning organizations and gun manufacturers have been denied access to financial services as a means to achieve policy goals outside of the political process. I foresee that the continued usage of demanding certain politically sensitive industries be denied access to financial services could lead to citizens being denied that same access because they affiliate with a certain political group. I believe that with the Fair Access to Financial Service rule in place, we can avoid such a catastrophe. I again am commenting in support of this rule and I hope that it is implemented.

text:
I support Fair Access to Financial Service, and believe it to be one of the most important pieces of regulation introduced at this time. Within recent memory, several potential services that might have acted as alternatives to many online platforms have been censored and deplatformed, and financial institutions/payment processors were the instigating forced used to accomplish this.

Sites like Gab have, in the past, presented themselves as alternatives to public forums of discussion such as Twitter, in response to their selective policing of speech. In response, payment processors refused to service them, effectively killing any competition for these massive social media websites in the cradle. Loss of monetary support is a death sentence, unless a business owner is willing to take alternative measures that many ordinary business owners may find to be cumbersome and opaque to them, such as the use of Cryptocurrency. This is simply not viable for most businesses, as revenue streams outside of primary payment processors are rarely used by the majority of citizens. Many business owners are concerned by this, but as a citizen I am arguably just as concerned.

Between the twin forces of financial institution's selective service and the monopoly on social media platforms it has created, the spirit of the First Amendment is being violated. Social media giants are free to police speech as they wish, and any competition or alternative is quickly silenced by payment processors, often based solely on an ideological basis. The internet has become a powerful tool for allowing people like me to freely communicate ideas, and the same is true for others. Often, I find myself in disagreement with the ideas being censored, but part of allowing free speech is allowing ideas I personally disagree with. I did not personally use Gab, but that does not mean that a website or service I do use will not be on the chopping block in the future.

A payment processor should only be allowed to refuse service to entities engaged in illegal activity. They should not be allowed to do so based on the personal opinions present within their own institution, or the perceived tide of public opinion. By allowing them to control who is and is not allowed to receive a citizen's money, we have allowed them too much power. Furthermore, as a private citizen I should be allowed to choose who I legally give business to however I wish. I'd be furious if I went to a local restaurant one day and was told I was not allowed to spend money there, and was instead forced to spend my money at a fast food chain down the road. Why should the internet be any different? Citizens should be allowed to support any business they wish, and right now doing so on the internet is quickly becoming impossible.

I am an ATM operator harmed by banks claiming perceptions of regulators possible actions.
My ATMs are located where many have little to no bank relationships and do not compete
with banks for card users. Card users often have no practical way to travel to bank ATMs,
and given the smaller withdrawals made, may have a net 30% expense if they did so.
I do not provide services at places such as casino's, dispenseries or malls.

I had my bank account closed without any cause by a major bank, and was told it was because
the compliance department was concerned the account would cause them problems with regulators.
All my account activity was visible to the bank for source of funds, had no unrelated activity,
and showed no cause to think funds were funneled to elsewhere, no mystery deposits or withdrawals.

At the time I opened the account, the bank also added an unsolicited credit card for me.
A few days later the compliance department called me to say they had closed the card account
because I was a "competitor" to the bank. They knew from the in office opening interview
that I mostly repaired ATMs and had only one ATM I operated at that time.

I have lived in the same home for over four decades and before that 10 blocks away for two decades.
I have a voting record not a crimminal record, my family members are well known in law enforcement
and Homeland Security, many have served in the military. I have a great credit score, no debt,
and multiple times in liquid assests the amount related to ATM activities.

The account closed was at my local neighborhood branch, and other banks in my neighborhood
refused to open an account for the same fear reasons.

Of the banks that said they would consider an account for my ATM activity, most added a flat monthly
fee to the account, in addition to the normal fees, because it was an "ATM business" account.
The fee amount ranged from $1,200 to $1,800 per month, while expected gross revenue was under $2,500.
This is a powerful way to block accounts without having to admit that decision.

I have heard from other ATM operators I know well in my northern California area
the same challenges with their bank accounts closed, even after 30 year relationships.

ATM operators have always suffered attacks upon their persons and their ATMs,
they should not experience the same at their bank.

Even though the OCC has said "Organizations involved in politically controversial but lawful businesses
(omitted)are entitled to fair access to financial services under the law." I am hearing local radio ads
from a bank BRAGGING about refusing to provide services to the tobacco industry.
I have no interest in the tobacco industry, this just shows how banks are actually operating.

I strongly support the OCC's proposed rule requiring fair and non-discriminatory access
to banking services for Independent ATM companies.
In addition to adopting the proposed rule, it is vital for the OCC to also pursue immediate
revision to the FFIEC Examination Manual section on "Privately Owned Automated Teller Machines",
in accordance with the suggested changes submitted by The National ATM Council.

Dear Sir or Madam:

I am writing to you today in support of the proposed rule change by the Comptroller of the Currency.

Like many Americans, I spend some amount of time on social media. This social media includes a forum called "Kiwi Farms" which discusses ongoing public controversies and has routinely been cut off from payment processors. In one regrettable case earlier this year, the cutoff occurred while a transaction was pending, causing both the site owner and his business partner to not have access to hundreds of dollars during a global pandemic and associated recession. To be clear, while this forum is controversial, neither the owner of Kiwi Farms nor the LLC which operates the site has ever been convicted of a crime. Rather, this arbitrary and capricious treatment comes from the forum's highly hands-off attitude towards entirely legal speech directed at "the wrong people", such as documenting scams and harassment perpetrated by the "in-crowd" of Silicon Valley.

This double standard becomes even more apparent and shameless when American banks have no problem handling genuinely illegal money (see e.g. this story of approximately $2 trillion in illegal money passing through mostly American banks: https://www.techtimes.com/articles/252708/20200920/worlds-big-bank-scandal-hsbc-barclays-allowing-2-trillion-worth-illegal-money.htm). Taken together this amounts to obvious censorship based on legitimate disagreement of viewpoints. Combined with the subsidies and protections for banks in Federal law, the idea that these are private companies and persons injured by them can take their business elsewhere is laughable.

In closing, I ask the OCC to adopt the "Fair Access to Financial Services" rule immediately.

To all whom it may concern (OCC, et. all),

I write this comment to express my affirmation of OCC and related agencies modifications and inclusions outlined in Docket ID OCC-2020-0042, referred to as the Fair Access to Financial Services. I write this regulation comment anonymously, as I value my personal privacy, however I will disclose that I am a relatively young adult United States citizen residing in Washington State.

The propositions outlined in the Fair Access to Financial Services by including new part 55, and its clauses, are a politically neutral and reasonable step towards securing the financial freedom for all citizens and foreigners conducting business within the United States. However, under the proposed § 55.1(a)(ii) and § 55.1(a)(iii), banks possessing less than $100 billion in total assets would be excluded from the definition of a covered bank, and the rest of these proposed regulations would not apply. Per the Federal Financial Institutions Examination Council-National Information Center web portal, as of 2020/06/30, Synchrony Financial would be excluded from these provisions, listing only approximately $97 billion in total assets [1]. Despite not meeting that financial bar, Synchrony Financial advertises serving over 75 million accounts [2], and while not comparing to the likes of J.P Morgen & Chase, still wields significant monetary authority over a wide swath of customers. My recommendation would be lowering the financial cut-off to $50 billion in total assets, though I recognize lowering the threshold could impact smaller businesses.

Of particular interest is that these regulations discourage payment processors from abusing their positions as monetary services providers for various primarily online services, preventing customers like myself from compensating and rendering payment towards websites and platforms we wish to use. The neutral video streaming service BitChute and competitor to YouTube was denied financial services from PayPal [3], without a quantitative assessment for their denial of services, likely politically motivated.

This past month, credit card providers Visa and Mastercard denied their services to the adult video streaming platform PornHub, prompted by claims that non-consensual, unlawful and harmful content was distributed using the website’s services [4]. While those claims likely have some merit, harmful content has on occasion been circulated on other platforms such as Twitter and Facebook, without payment processors suddenly denying related services to those platforms for use of advertisement purchases or the like. The alternate free-speech focused platform, which could be viewed as a competitor to Twitter, had their financial services provided by Stripe suddenly dropped after the tragic incident involving a member of the service. A representative claimed that Gab fully cooperated with law enforcement after the incident, but was denied financial services for providing a platform to unpopular and politically vile speech [5].

As the world continues to network and communicate using online platforms, I firmly believe that financial liberty retains its value, equal to that of Free Speech as enshrined in the Bill of Rights. As outlined in the cited regulation revisions, these financial firms are free to dispute and deny their services, so long as they provide quantitative, unbiased proof that financial dealing with the customer would expose them and their clients to direct financial risk. If monetary services providers wish to discriminate on the grounds of political decisions, they must be treated as financial institutions distinct from banks. While my opinions are sourced from news and personal beliefs, I reiterate that these regulations will neutrally benefit all online users and businesses alike, regardless of political affiliation or other categorizations.

Sincerely,

text:
The Comptroller of the Currency ("OCC") should enact the proposed rule FAIR ACCESS TO FINANCIAL SERVICES as currently written. The rule reaffirms decades of OCC guidance stating that banks cannot deny or limit financial services to broad groups of individuals for reasons other than objective factors such as creditworthiness, ability to pay, and other impartial risk-based factors. This rule is consistent with the OCC's duties as noted under title III of the Dodd–Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010, which states the OCC is responsible for "assuring the safety and soundness of, and compliance with laws and regulations, fair access to financial services, and fair treatment of customers by, the institutions and other persons subject to its jurisdiction".

The need for such a rule is unfortunate but necessary in light of the hijacking of the financial system by politicians, special interest groups, and political activists. These groups have used banks and other financial institutions to attack political rivals and/or citizens engaged in legal but politically controversial industries or activities such as firearms, coal, and payday lending. Political disagreements should be expressed and resolved in public by Congress and State Legislatures, not by business executives and political activists. Efforts by political groups to weaponize the financial system to "cancel" their opponents are illegal, undemocratic, and toxic to social cohesiveness. The OCC should pass and strictly enforce this rule to ensure banks and political activists stay in their lane and that the constitutional rights of all Americans are protected.
